material.mattext: Based on the output, comment on the (statistical) significance of the results, and state your conclusions in context.

Here is the R output:
> p = prop.test(78,400,0.2,alternative="less",conf.level=0.95, correct=FALSE); p
1-sample proportions test without continuity correction
data: 78 out of 400, null probability 0.2 X-squared = 0.0625, df = 1, p-value = 0.4013 alternative hypothesis: true p is less than 0.2 95 percent confidence interval: 0.0000000 0.2295887 sample estimates: p 0.195
> z = -sqrt(p$statistic); z X-squared -0.25
Based on the large p-value (0.401) we conclude that the results are not statistically significant. In other words, the data does not provide evidence to conclude that the proportion of defective products has been reduced.
